lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are
instructions on how to use it.
### Using Gradle Wrapper from the command line
1. Open a terminal and navigate to the project root folder (the folder containing this `README.md` file).
1. Run the following command to build and run the project:
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.
1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/simon/Simon.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Simon.main()` (if the
code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something
like the below as the output:
**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move
Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle)
The project has the following structure:
To run the unit tests, you can use the Gradle wrapper from the command line:
This will execute all tests in the project and display the results in the terminal.

<AnchorPane maxHeight="-Infinity" maxWidth="-Infinity" minHeight="-Infinity" minWidth="-Infinity" prefHeight="600.0" prefWidth="400.0" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/17" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1" fx:controller="simon.ui.MainWindow">
<!-- Header: anchored to top so it stays visible while content scrolls -->

<HBox fx:id="headerBox" alignment="CENTER_LEFT" prefHeight="50.0" prefWidth="388.0" spacing="10.0" styleClass="sticky-header" AnchorPane.leftAnchor="8.0" AnchorPane.rightAnchor="8.0" AnchorPane.topAnchor="0.0">
<!-- Scrollable area: placed below header and above the input controls -->

<ScrollPane fx:id="scrollPane" fitToWidth="true" hbarPolicy="NEVER" hvalue="1.0" prefHeight="557.0" prefWidth="400.0" vvalue="1.0" AnchorPane.bottomAnchor="60.0" AnchorPane.leftAnchor="0.0" AnchorPane.rightAnchor="0.0" AnchorPane.topAnchor="50.0">
<!-- Input area: anchored to bottom as a styled HBox -->
<HBox fx:id="inputBox" alignment="CENTER_LEFT" spacing="8.0" AnchorPane.bottomAnchor="8.0" AnchorPane.leftAnchor="8.0" AnchorPane.rightAnchor="8.0">
<TextField fx:id="userInput" onAction="#handleUserInput" prefHeight="40.0" promptText="Type a message..." styleClass="input-field" HBox.hgrow="ALWAYS" />
<Button fx:id="sendButton" mnemonicParsing="false" onAction="#handleUserInput" prefHeight="40.0" prefWidth="56.0" styleClass="send-button" text="➤" />
This project uses JUnit for testing. Below are some common commands to run and manage tests using Gradle.
In IntelliJ, you can right-click on a test class or method and select "Run" to execute tests directly from the IDE or double press Ctrl to run the commands with gradle.
To use the compiled .jar file for testing, you can run the following commands:
gh release create v1.0.0 ./build/libs/simon-1.0.0.jar --repo jolenechong/ip --title "v1.0.0" --notes "Release up to A-jar increments"
* This test verifies that the main method of the Simon application
* correctly prints the greeting message and exits upon receiving the "bye" command.
* It will use simon-test-home as temp user home directory and send "bye" as input.
* Tests that the main method prints the greeting and exits on "bye" command.
* @throws Exception if any I/O error occurs during the test.
assertTrue(printed.contains("Hello! I'm Simon!"), "Main should print the greeting with name Simon");
assertTrue(printed.contains("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!"), "Main should print the farewell on exit");
* Unit tests for the UI class.
* Restores original System.out and System.in after each test.
* Tests that sayHi prints the correct greeting message with the provided name.
System.setIn(new ByteArrayInputStream(new byte[0])); // avoid blocking scanner
assertTrue(printed.contains("Hello! I'm Tester!"), "sayHi should include the provided name");
assertTrue(printed.contains("What can I do for you?"), "sayHi should include the prompt");
* Tests that sayBye prints the correct farewell message.
assertTrue(printed.contains("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!"), "sayBye should print farewell message");
* Tests that println, printAll, and printError work as expected.
assertTrue(printed.contains("simple line"), "println should print the message");
assertTrue(printed.contains("formatted text"), "printAll should format and print the message");
assertTrue(printed.contains("error occurred"), "printError should print the error message");
* Tests that readLine correctly reads and trims input.
assertEquals("hello world", line, "readLine should trim surrounding whitespace");
Only the runtest.sh script is updated.
To run the text UI tests, execute the following command in your terminal:
REM create bin directory if it doesn't exist

REM run the program, feed commands from input.txt file and redirect the output to the ACTUAL.TXT

# run the program, feed commands from input.txt file and redirect the output to the ACTUAL.TXT
# compare the output to the expected output
